Regression Coefficients \(\boldsymbol{\hat{\beta}}\) - Singular Value Decomposition

Source: R/betahat.R
dot-betahatsvd.Rd

Estimates coefficients of a linear regression model using Singular Value Decomposition. The data matrix \(\mathbf{X}\) is decomposed into $$ \mathbf{X} = \mathbf{U} \mathbf{\Sigma} \mathbf{V}^{T} . $$ Estimates are found by solving $$ \boldsymbol{\hat{\beta}} = \mathbf{V} \mathbf{\Sigma}^{+} \mathbf{U}^{T} \mathbf{y} $$ where the superscript \(+\) indicates the pseudoinverse.

.betahatsvd(X, y)

Arguments

X

n by k numeric matrix. The data matrix \(\mathbf{X}\) (also known as design matrix, model matrix or regressor matrix) is an \(n \times k\) matrix of \(n\) observations of \(k\) regressors, which includes a regressor whose value is 1 for each observation on the first column.
y

Numeric vector of length n or n by 1 matrix. The vector \(\mathbf{y}\) is an \(n \times 1\) vector of observations on the regressand variable.

Value

Returns \(\boldsymbol{\hat{\beta}}\), that is, a \(k \times 1\) vector of estimates of \(k\) unknown regression coefficients estimated using ordinary least squares.

References

Wikipedia: Linear regression

Wikipedia: Ordinary least squares

Wikipedia: Singular value decomposition

Wikipedia: Orthogonal decomposition methods

Wikipedia: Design matrix

See also

Other beta-hat functions: .betahatnorm(), .betahatqr(), betahat()

Examples

X <- jeksterslabRdatarepo::wages.matrix[["X"]]
# age is removed
X <- X[, -ncol(X)]
y <- jeksterslabRdatarepo::wages.matrix[["y"]]
.betahatsvd(X = X, y = y)
#>         betahat
#> [1,] -7.1833382
#> [2,] -3.0748755
#> [3,] -1.5653133
#> [4,]  1.0959758
#> [5,]  1.3703010
#> [6,]  0.1666065
